contentrichtext.text: {{Orphan|date=February 2009}} '''''The Interpretation of Music''''' is a book by Prof. [[Thurston Dart]]. It is described by the [[EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica]] as "the best direct and concise account of the issues of performance".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/399251/musical-performance |title=Musical Performance |work=[[Britannica Online]] |accessdate=2008-10-25 |format=select "Additional reading"}}</ref> This book deals with correct performance conventions and procedures relevant to different periods and styles (for example Gregorian intonation, divisions upon parts, French [[baroque]] over-dotting, etc.). It covers these various topics in a chronological order, also giving descriptions of period instruments and their uses. It is a book useful for those wishing to compose in a more authentic antiquated style, and for those wishing to make performances more historically "correct". ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Interpretation Of Music, The}} [[Category:Music books]] {{music-publication-stub}}
